definition: to guard/to protect/to defend/abbr. for 衛生|卫生, hygiene/health/abbr. for 衛生間|卫生间, toilet
surname Wei/vassal state during the Zhou Dynasty (1066-221 BC), located in present day Henan and Hebei Provinces

sentences.english: Tian Taiquan accompanied us to go to the Red Army Graveyard the next day.
sentences.chinese: 第二天田太权陪我们几个去那个红卫兵墓上看看。

sentences.english: Mao Zedong's Red Guards sometimes called themselves “new Boxers”.
sentences.chinese: 红卫兵有时自称“新义和团”。

sentences.english: Millions of radical youths came to be known around the world as the Red Guards
sentences.chinese: 数百万激进的年轻人成为世界广为知道的红卫兵。

sentences.english: Its waitresses dress as Red Guards.
sentences.chinese: 它的店员穿的都像红卫兵。

sentences.english: Red Guards swarmed there for ritual denunciations of Liu and his ilk.
sentences.chinese: 红卫兵蜂拥而至，在此举行仪式批判刘和刘的亲属。

sentences.english: Red Guards swarmed there for ritual denunciations of Liu and his ilk.
sentences.chinese: 无数红卫兵在这里给刘及其同类人开批斗大会。

sentences.english: If you didn't follow the Red Guards maybe one day they would criticize you.
sentences.chinese: 如果不追随红卫兵的话，或许有一天他们回来批斗你。

sentences.english: Mao Zedong’s Red Guards sometimes called themselves “new Boxers”.
sentences.chinese: 红卫兵有时自称“新义和团”。

definition: to seize and subject to public criticism (form of persecution during the Cultural Revolution)
capitalist roader (person in power taking the capitalist road, a political label often pinned on cadres by the Red Guards during the Cultural Revolution)
Cultural Revolution (1966-76)/abbr. for 文化大革命[Wen2 hua4 Da4 ge2 ming4]
Destroy the Four Olds (campaign of the Cultural Revolution)
to drag sb before a public meeting to denounce, humiliate and physically abuse them (esp. during the Cultural Revolution)
Gang of Four: Jiang Qing 江青, Zhang Chunqiao 張春橋, Yao Wenyuan 姚文元, Wang Hongwen 王洪文, who served as scapegoats for the excesses of the cultural revolution

(category defined by the Communist Party) poor and lower-middle peasants: farmers who, before land reform, possessed little or no land (poor peasants) and those who were barely able to support themselves with their own land (lower-middle peasants)
the Four Olds (target of the Cultural Revolution)
